behind him, but, like the burning OF Moscow,
it was mastery; for Massena being thus de-
prived Of the means of supplying his army,
was soon obliged to retracc his steps to
Spain, pursued in his turn by the British,
and leaving the roads covered with his starv-
ing people, and slaughtered horses.


Amidst this desolaton first saw the lit
tie hero of whom write. had been with
the rear guard of the division. and was APP
preaching Abandra, when | observed four
or five men standing on ridge, in the val
lev through which VIC were pressing. One
OF them ran towards me, and said that there
was a man lying under "A tree u little way oil
the road, beside stream, and that he was
dying. staff surgeon WAS close by; told
him the circumstance, and We Immediately
proce ctlcd to the spot. There we beheld
soldier lying upon his back, his head resting
against bank, his cap beside him ana tllled
with water as ii he had been drinking out OF
it. Beside the man sat a fine boy, about three
wears cid, bis little arms stretched across him.
The Child looked wisttully atus We ask
ed him what be was doing there? but from


fright and perhaps confusion At seeing us all
intent upon ques.inning him, he only burst


into tears. The surgeon examined the man
and found he was litcless but still warm. !
asked the child il the man was his tathcr!


he said lie was; brt TO any further questions


he could only lisp an unintellisibe answer.
The surgeon thought the man had died oi
fatigue, probably from marching while, un-
der great debility Of sickness. asked the
boy, if he had walked with father that day
and he replied, that he did not, but had been
carried by him.


At this moment the last Of the division
was passing up the hill, and the French col
uuns appeared about halfa mile behind


There was nothing to be done but to remove
the child. and leave the dead man as ne was
directed the soldiers to do so, and to bring
him along with them. They accordingly


went over to the boy, to take him away from
the body, but he cried out, While tears roll
ed from his eyes, ".No, no. me a!ay az 0aa-
ly!-me stay wi daddy." and clung his 1T
tie arms about TIE dead soldier with deter


mined grasp. The men looked at each
ther; we we're all affected in the same way;
could ,.e the tears in the hardy fellows,
eyes They carcsscd him; they promised


that his father should so also; but no, the
\ little aifectionate creature could not be per-


suaded to quit his hold. Force was necessa-


~; the men drew him away from the body;


but the child's cries were heart-rendlng'


+" DaQdy dQddy daddy dear, dear daa-


dy!' Thus he called and cried, while tine


men, endeavorng to soothe him, bore him up
! the hill lust as tho enemy were entering the


valley. This was little Johnny, and the deao


man was his fathers kind, gond- -heartcd


comrade, who perhaps fastened MS own


death in carrying the beloved little orphan

AS soon as we had reached the town,
preparations were made for ascending the
hills to see a party of Islanders descend the
precipices TOR the cider down, aud for eggs
and BIRDS Five of these twisted round their
bodies diagonally, from the left shoulder to
to the hip, the rope made use Of for these
occasions. One Of these ropes forms the por-
ton of St. ki'sia heii ess; it is always a cur
rent coin of the highest value, life itself de-
pending On the possession OF it. Equipped
with these ropes, strong party, with their
dogs, assembled the hills.


At length we reached the brink of such
tremendous precipice, that, accustomed as
have been, to regard such sights with in
difference, / dal,. d not venture to the edge Of
it alone Two Of the people held my arms,
and | looked over INTO what might be Il
world Of rolling mists, and col.tcnding clouds.
/ AS they broke, or dispersed, the ocean was
disclosed below hut at so great depth,
that its roaring surges were unheard ut this
stupendous height. The brink was wet and
slippery, and the rocks perpendicular to
their base; but what was my astonishmcnt
to see these intrepid :rronauts, as they might
truly be called, sitting on the edge and the
younger ones creeping over after the eggs
and aisic corks.


| NV attention was now entirely engrossed
bv the adventurers, who were preparing
for their dangerous fight :--several ropes of
hide and hair we're tied together to extend
the depth of his descent. a rope OF hide at
one extremity, was fastened like girdle
round his waist, the other end he let down
the precipcc to considerable depth, when
giving the middle OF the rope to a single
m an who stood near him, lie began to de-
scend, always holding by one part of the
rope as he let himself down by the other.
and supported from falling only by the man
above, who hnt, no part of the rope fasten-
ed to him, but held i, merely in his hands,
and sometimes supported him by one hard
alone, looking at the same time over the
precipice, without any stay for his feet. and
conversing with the young man as he de-
scendcd. In very short time he returned
with a young fulmar in his hand, and then
again descended 70 the depth Of sixty faith
otns. Here he seized four fIllmars, with
two in each hand, continued to holl the rope
as he assembled, striking his foot against the
rock to throw himself out from the face OF
the precipice and returned with bound
few out again, capering and shouting, and
,laving more tricks than / had courage tc
see; for expected his love Of fame, in dis
PLAYING those gambols to a stranger, woult
either be the means of pulling the mar over
who held him, or dashing his brains ont
from the violence of which he returned from
these springs, if the rope did not slip from
his comrades hand, and send him headlons
to eternity.
From the Life of DR.. Clark.

With respect to the slave population, It
may be remarked that it has greatly chan
yed its character within few years, SO tar as
Havana and Matanzas are conccrned,and al
so in other places of any magnitude. On the
plantations there is nece ssarily, from the situ-
alton OF the slaves, but little improvement.
There is an air of independence, manliness,
and sclf-consequencc about the negroes


which have never seen in my own coun-
trv. At the same time the laws OF Havana
or. such. that if a negro raises his arm 60
strike n white, the latter may Kill! him with
;mnnnitv. In confirmation of this opinion


would remark. that the same opinion comes
almost irresjstablv on the mind OF every TO-


r.;rncr the moment he touches the mole at


Havana. | have frs iuently seen negro
stop gentleman in the street, ana request
ncrmi,sion to light a scgar by one winch the
gentleman was smoking; and what surprised


me more. was. that in all cases the request

have as often heard gentlemen make the

cent date, and how it came to pass re re-

mors of Washington.


The public day of the First President OF
the United States, were two in each week.
On Tuesday from three to four o'clock,
Ievee was held for Foreign Ministers, stran-
gers. and others, who could there be pre-
sented to the Chief Magistrate, without the
formaity Of letters Of introduction. 1t was,
indeed, more an arrangement oi mutual con
venierce to the parties, than an ALTAR OF
State; still 1t was objected to by some at that
day. as savoring rather of monarchai eti-
ouette, than OF the simple customs which
should distinguish Republic. Who thinks
so now? In truth, the First President was
so occupied with the multiplicity OF public
concerns, attendant on the outset OF a new
Government, that it became necessary to
limit the time of vsiters Of mere cermony,
as much as possible; and the levee enabled
all such personages to pay 't"ir respects
within the moderate compass OF an honr.-
The world is always governed in consider
able degree by form and usage, There ney.
er lived man more averse to SHOW and
nomp than Washington. PLAIN IN his hab-
its, there was none to whoa the details OF
official parade and ceremony could be less
leSlraDIe, Dul CCiISCS ~ an no f"'iNh
stations of life, the days Of the First Presi-
dency will ever appear as among the most
digniiied and imposing in our country's an
mails.


On Thursday the President gave his con-
gressional and Diplomatic dinners; and on
Friday night Mrs. Washington received
company at what was then, and is still, cal
led the Drawing Room.


The President attended Mrs. Washing
toms evening parties, and paid his compi-
ments to the circle Of ladies, with that ease
and elegance of manners for which he was
remarkable. Among the most polished and
we'll bred gentlemen of his time. he was al
ways particularly polite to ladies', even II,
the rugged scenes of war; and, in advanced
age, many were the youthful swains who
sighed for those gracious smiles with which
the Fair always received the attentions o.
this old beau of sixtyhve.


! An interesting class of persons were t'
be fount! at the side of the Chief, on both hi!
public and private days, who gave feeling
and character to every scene, and threw

Notwithstanding his great occupation in
public affairs, the First President by no
means neglected his private concerns. He
was in the habit of receiving regular and
lengthy reports from the agents of his es.
tates in Virginia. and directed by letter the
management of these extensive establish
ments, with both consumate skill and sue
cess He also inspected the weekly accounts
and disbursements of his household in Phila-
delpha. Indeed, nothing seemed to es-
cape the seeming mind of this wonderful
man, "who had time for all things, and did
every thing in its proper time" and in order.


General Washington was practical econ-
omist; while he wished that his style of liv-
ing should be fully in character with his ex-
alted station, he was utterly averse to waste
or extravaganza of any sort. He frequently
reprimanded his first steward Francis, (the
same at whose hotel in New-York the Gem
eral in Chief took leave Of his brother Off
cers.) for expenditures which appeared to
be both unnecessary and extrayagant Fran
els once purchased shad fish at AN unusual
season; it was served up at the Presidents
private table, who remarked that it was vel
ry early for such fish to be in the market.
and demanded the price; the answer was,
three dollars. Washington waved his hand,
and ordered, take it away, Sir; it must new
er be said that my table sets an example of
extravaganza. The mortified Steward re.
moved the rarity untouched.


The First President took considerable
pains, and used frequent stratagens, in en-
deavoring to avoid the numberless manifes.
tations Of attachment and respect which a.
waited him wherever he went. On his Jour-
neys, he charged the courier who would
proceed to engage accommodations at the
inns, by no means to mention the coming of
the President to other than the landlord.-
These precautions but rarely took effect.
and often, when the Chief would suppose
that he had stolen a march upon his old
companions in arms and fellow citizens, a
horseman would be discovered dashing off
at ful speed, and soon would be heard the
trumpet of the volunteer cavalry, and the
village cannon, reused from its bed of ne
glect, where it had lain since warlike times.
would summon I'll within reach of its echoes,
to haste and bid welcome to the man who
was "frst in the hearts of his countrymen."
Every village and little hamlet poured forth
their population to greet the arrival of him
whom all delighted to honor. A kind ofju-
bilee attended every where the progress of
the Patriot Chief; for even the school chill


lren, with the curiosity incident to that age
of innocence, would labor hard at the daily
lesson, and leave the birch to hang idly on
the wall, when to see Gencroi Washington
was the expected holiday and reward; and
many of these children, now the parents of
children, while recalling the golden hours
of infancy, will dwell with delight on the
time when they were presented to the Pa
ternal Chief, and recount how they heard
the kindly sounds of his voice; felt the kind
lier touch of his hand; or climbed his knee,
to "share the good mans SMILE" Pure.
HAPPY and honored recollections! they will
descend like tradtionary lore from gener-
alton to generation, venerable to all future
| time.


In the frequent trial of generalship be-
tween the Chief and his ancient comrades
in arms-the one seeking to avoid the testi-


monies of respect and attachment, which the
0ther was equally Stud1ouS TO oHer-tne latc
Colonel Proctor, gallant and distinguished
officer of Artillery, was several times OUT
generalled-the President having reached


the Seat of Government privately and un-


observed. This reused the good old Colo
mel, who declared, ale shall not serve me


SO again; I'll warrant that my matches will


be found lighted next time"


So soon as the first gun would be heard


from the upper extremity of Market street,


venerable citizen was seen to leave his Of


Ace, and moving at more than his usual pace.


ascend the steps of the Presidolead He


gave in no name; he required no ceremony
of introduction, but, making his way to the


family parlor, opened the general gratula-


lation by the first welcome Of Robert Nor.


ris.

Washington to his house. 1t was his claim,


his privilege: like the claims at Corona


ton. it had been put in and allowed, and.
verify, the veteran would not have yielded
it to an Emperor.

full articles.article:
behind him, but, like the burning OF Moscow,
it was mastery; for Massena being thus de-
prived Of the means of supplying his army,
was soon obliged to retracc his steps to
Spain, pursued in his turn by the British,
and leaving the roads covered with his starv-
ing people, and slaughtered horses.


Amidst this desolaton first saw the lit
tie hero of whom write. had been with
the rear guard of the division. and was APP
preaching Abandra, when | observed four
or five men standing on ridge, in the val
lev through which VIC were pressing. One
OF them ran towards me, and said that there
was a man lying under "A tree u little way oil
the road, beside stream, and that he was
dying. staff surgeon WAS close by; told
him the circumstance, and We Immediately
proce ctlcd to the spot. There we beheld
soldier lying upon his back, his head resting
against bank, his cap beside him ana tllled
with water as ii he had been drinking out OF
it. Beside the man sat a fine boy, about three
wears cid, bis little arms stretched across him.
The Child looked wisttully atus We ask
ed him what be was doing there? but from


fright and perhaps confusion At seeing us all
intent upon ques.inning him, he only burst


into tears. The surgeon examined the man
and found he was litcless but still warm. !
asked the child il the man was his tathcr!


he said lie was; brt TO any further questions


he could only lisp an unintellisibe answer.
The surgeon thought the man had died oi
fatigue, probably from marching while, un-
der great debility Of sickness. asked the
boy, if he had walked with father that day
and he replied, that he did not, but had been
carried by him.


At this moment the last Of the division
was passing up the hill, and the French col
uuns appeared about halfa mile behind


There was nothing to be done but to remove
the child. and leave the dead man as ne was
directed the soldiers to do so, and to bring
him along with them. They accordingly


went over to the boy, to take him away from
the body, but he cried out, While tears roll
ed from his eyes, ".No, no. me a!ay az 0aa-
ly!-me stay wi daddy." and clung his 1T
tie arms about TIE dead soldier with deter


mined grasp. The men looked at each
ther; we we're all affected in the same way;
could ,.e the tears in the hardy fellows,
eyes They carcsscd him; they promised


that his father should so also; but no, the
\ little aifectionate creature could not be per-


suaded to quit his hold. Force was necessa-


~; the men drew him away from the body;


but the child's cries were heart-rendlng'


+" DaQdy dQddy daddy dear, dear daa-


dy!' Thus he called and cried, while tine


men, endeavorng to soothe him, bore him up
! the hill lust as tho enemy were entering the


valley. This was little Johnny, and the deao


man was his fathers kind, gond- -heartcd


comrade, who perhaps fastened MS own


death in carrying the beloved little orphan

full articles.headline:
From the Life of DR.. Clark.

Descent Of Birdcatchers oper the Precipices Of 81


Erdd.
full articles.article:
AS soon as we had reached the town,
preparations were made for ascending the
hills to see a party of Islanders descend the
precipices TOR the cider down, aud for eggs
and BIRDS Five of these twisted round their
bodies diagonally, from the left shoulder to
to the hip, the rope made use Of for these
occasions. One Of these ropes forms the por-
ton of St. ki'sia heii ess; it is always a cur
rent coin of the highest value, life itself de-
pending On the possession OF it. Equipped
with these ropes, strong party, with their
dogs, assembled the hills.


At length we reached the brink of such
tremendous precipice, that, accustomed as
have been, to regard such sights with in
difference, / dal,. d not venture to the edge Of
it alone Two Of the people held my arms,
and | looked over INTO what might be Il
world Of rolling mists, and col.tcnding clouds.
/ AS they broke, or dispersed, the ocean was
disclosed below hut at so great depth,
that its roaring surges were unheard ut this
stupendous height. The brink was wet and
slippery, and the rocks perpendicular to
their base; but what was my astonishmcnt
to see these intrepid :rronauts, as they might
truly be called, sitting on the edge and the
younger ones creeping over after the eggs
and aisic corks.


| NV attention was now entirely engrossed
bv the adventurers, who were preparing
for their dangerous fight :--several ropes of
hide and hair we're tied together to extend
the depth of his descent. a rope OF hide at
one extremity, was fastened like girdle
round his waist, the other end he let down
the precipcc to considerable depth, when
giving the middle OF the rope to a single
m an who stood near him, lie began to de-
scend, always holding by one part of the
rope as he let himself down by the other.
and supported from falling only by the man
above, who hnt, no part of the rope fasten-
ed to him, but held i, merely in his hands,
and sometimes supported him by one hard
alone, looking at the same time over the
precipice, without any stay for his feet. and
conversing with the young man as he de-
scendcd. In very short time he returned
with a young fulmar in his hand, and then
again descended 70 the depth Of sixty faith
otns. Here he seized four fIllmars, with
two in each hand, continued to holl the rope
as he assembled, striking his foot against the
rock to throw himself out from the face OF
the precipice and returned with bound
few out again, capering and shouting, and
,laving more tricks than / had courage tc
see; for expected his love Of fame, in dis
PLAYING those gambols to a stranger, woult
either be the means of pulling the mar over
who held him, or dashing his brains ont
from the violence of which he returned from
these springs, if the rope did not slip from
his comrades hand, and send him headlons
to eternity.

full articles.headline: yyILARToN AND AUREA..
full articles.article:
1t was lovely sight to witness wheh' re-
turning from his toll or mountain sport, HI
iaron reached his home. BY the rude aoor
grew sycamor. and lines, whose ooushs
hung down like woman's tresscs, ana around
whose trunks the honeysuckle wound 'ts
fragrant arms; and laurel, always green ana
myrtles, which shook their white nuas DC,
Neath the summer moon, were there' anu
;here, expecting his return, the gentle Au'
ria, who, each happy day, gathered her fa,r. AZ r.
est fruits to welcome him. Soft was tue
evenings greeting;-one long kiss, received
and given, told a world Of love; and many
a question asked how absence passed was
answered senderly, and lovely fears at 'ih CO
would fill the eye and ease thetheart.


One child, like Auria fair, (and with sucn
locks as Hebe might, in early infancy nave ,
cast on Juno, when that skiey queen nrs'
showed her unto Jove smilng) was Dorm
Agentle link of love, yet frmer far tha'
'onds (though useful these) or forced VOWS
vas that fair child, who from each paren.
heart drew Joy; and by communicative sisn
more beautiful than words) and murn'ur
sounds, (nature's imperfect utterance') 'ol'
It's own, and carried to the others hearts ae
light.


Gentle and welded love, how tar az
mou--how rich, how very rich, yet iree
Hblame, how calm and how secure'-'.'


perfect hours pass onward to futurlty VIII

full articles.headline: CUB& TET 1897.
full articles.article:
With respect to the slave population, It
may be remarked that it has greatly chan
yed its character within few years, SO tar as
Havana and Matanzas are conccrned,and al
so in other places of any magnitude. On the
plantations there is nece ssarily, from the situ-
alton OF the slaves, but little improvement.
There is an air of independence, manliness,
and sclf-consequencc about the negroes


which have never seen in my own coun-
trv. At the same time the laws OF Havana
or. such. that if a negro raises his arm 60
strike n white, the latter may Kill! him with
;mnnnitv. In confirmation of this opinion


would remark. that the same opinion comes
almost irresjstablv on the mind OF every TO-


r.;rncr the moment he touches the mole at


Havana. | have frs iuently seen negro
stop gentleman in the street, ana request
ncrmi,sion to light a scgar by one winch the
gentleman was smoking; and what surprised


me more. was. that in all cases the request
was granted without the least hesitation.
have as often heard gentlemen make the
same request of the negroes. inquired oi
Young Cuban if such things were not OF re-
cent date, and how it came to pass re re-
plied that until within few years 1t was
not known; that it had become necessary %
he more civil to them than torhefiy; tnat
he himself possessed Al slaves, but thae ne
wished the island might be free notwith-
standing. and added with much emphasis,
"manana, manana," tomorrow, tomorrow.


The soldiers form part of thepopulation OF


Havana distinct in feeling from the others :


,,o,, occasion to converse with them on the out
nosts. in order to ascertain their feelings to-


wards the king, and the government OF the ISL
! and knowing that from the officers their true


onin;ons could not be learned. One young


soldier of % ears told me, that he had been


fnrced into the army when quite young, and
that subsequently he had been seht to Cuba
fo,, a term of six years, but added, "oix


means twenty; have but little hope OF re-


turning, and the greater part OF the oattaiion


are in the same condition" AS the news OF
tbe war between Spain and Portugal, had


arrived but short time previous. and Mr.
Canning's speech was published, inquired
,f him what he would do il the English
came to attack him in the Nero! "Would
that this might be SO. tor then should re-


,,,rn the sooner" Another soldier made the


s,m- remark. and used the same word i'll


reference to the English, (oxaia! oxalaD-
These small things, together with others o.
=, a kind, served to show the feelings OF the sol


diers. -, =,
1t may be remarked, with regard to tht


different classes, it is very difficult tor for
eipner to distinguish between the negro anI
! white population. Cubans in. general ar


darker than the Spaniards of the mothe
5 country. Indeed there is no standard; TO
: the grades exist from the light brown to th
Goa, black of Africa, and the extreme hea
/ Of Cuba giving the curl to this hair after

full articles.headline:
CEREBRAL WASHINGTON,

His Life, Habits and manners-.7necdofes.
full articles.article:
HIS LIFE, Ha6ifs and mdnhefS-.f"tcHOffS.
From the Gusts Ieecollections and Private Me-


mors of Washington.


The public day of the First President OF
the United States, were two in each week.
On Tuesday from three to four o'clock,
Ievee was held for Foreign Ministers, stran-
gers. and others, who could there be pre-
sented to the Chief Magistrate, without the
formaity Of letters Of introduction. 1t was,
indeed, more an arrangement oi mutual con
venierce to the parties, than an ALTAR OF
State; still 1t was objected to by some at that
day. as savoring rather of monarchai eti-
ouette, than OF the simple customs which
should distinguish Republic. Who thinks
so now? In truth, the First President was
so occupied with the multiplicity OF public
concerns, attendant on the outset OF a new
Government, that it became necessary to
limit the time of vsiters Of mere cermony,
as much as possible; and the levee enabled
all such personages to pay 't"ir respects
within the moderate compass OF an honr.-
The world is always governed in consider
able degree by form and usage, There ney.
er lived man more averse to SHOW and
nomp than Washington. PLAIN IN his hab-
its, there was none to whoa the details OF
official parade and ceremony could be less
leSlraDIe, Dul CCiISCS ~ an no f"'iNh
stations of life, the days Of the First Presi-
dency will ever appear as among the most
digniiied and imposing in our country's an
mails.


On Thursday the President gave his con-
gressional and Diplomatic dinners; and on
Friday night Mrs. Washington received
company at what was then, and is still, cal
led the Drawing Room.


The President attended Mrs. Washing
toms evening parties, and paid his compi-
ments to the circle Of ladies, with that ease
and elegance of manners for which he was
remarkable. Among the most polished and
we'll bred gentlemen of his time. he was al
ways particularly polite to ladies', even II,
the rugged scenes of war; and, in advanced
age, many were the youthful swains who
sighed for those gracious smiles with which
the Fair always received the attentions o.
this old beau of sixtyhve.


! An interesting class of persons were t'
be fount! at the side of the Chief, on both hi!
public and private days, who gave feeling
and character to every scene, and threw

We are bos,ening on---we are fastening On,
ro tbc slcep of Tie years, that are vanished ana


gone,


~ ,h,. vo;c,less chambcrs that liz bcncath,-

Jile Inc instant nashinr,--thc h''ul light,

Like thc sunset hucs. or the s''ulnet'H eve,
like the forms, that in fancy y loom we "eaVe'

We arc blnshing and blooming ana ilfin' away
Through Hfc's chcckcrc'l macs o l"' ~ w,
Through the grief and lhe st'"'1 o" ''' '''e


below,
with the fir, and the brave, ard the proud and


the just,
We arc fastening TO dust W. are ha:tenlng To


dust!


=, beautiful Throne. Of the blirl.t and far,
WIN your locks of glossy and golden ha'r,
tu;tl, our sn,rl,ing ewes, and their rays divine,
-rb,t lonn,lishlv beam or brilliantly sh,ne'
with vour crimson lips aud them coral strali'
A. .,,,oot oe the wave uttered songs ofthe man;
win vour forms that before Us, and round us


sweep, =
like thc phantoms that float in the realms q


slecp,-
Midst hope, and Joy, and faith, and trust,
Yc are Fastening 10 dust We are has'eh'hs 10


dust


Ye pluincl band Oi the strong ahu '''t p''N',
With your FURNISHED swords, and pi'lmeS u'''


wave!


With your banners that stream OH their brcezes


unfurlcd, ,,.
And YOUR shouts that frightcn the trembling
world;
With ym,r battles that burst like flaming Hood,
And pour out their gathered tides oi blood;
with your rcd cannon wrath and warthat make
The mountains, the valleys the oceans quakci
With YOU, barred arms, and your lifted lance,
And vour blackcning brow, and Jour teartu


glance,


Midst the sabr's stroke, and the dagger's thurs
Ye are Fastening to dust! Ye are fastening e


dust!


yc scoffing tribe, Of the rich and proud,
With your necks unbcnt, and your knees IN


bowed
with vonr mnion train OF the mean and vie,
That crouch before yon, and fawn and smile,
With your spurning foot, and your threat ninI


eye,


That stagger the poor as they pass YOU by;
with your menancing tones of wrath and pride
That frighten the fearful who wait At Nor side
With vonr smiles Of scorn, AID Your irowns c


hate,


with your robes of gold. and Your halls OF state
With all your po,np, and power, and trust,
Ye are Fastening 10 Dust Yc are fastening I


dust!


Yc lovely train Of the humble and meek.
Who wipc the tear from the aged cheek
Whose voice the gathering cares hegu'ie.
And mnketh the hearts of the sad to smile,
With your tears that stream Ger the ch'iiih


bier


Of the pious that dwell no longer here
With your smiles that Dint up The broken heHF
And pour balm on the poisonous dart,
With your prayer, that rise to the throne apo.' ,,
And bring down the blessing OF peace ana ov'
With the fair and the brave, an'l the prouH III


the just, ,.....,.
u -, c.

thee, without sigh or backward lock OF
sorrow:--Pleasantly on they pass, never de
laycd by doubt, emorse, or desperate fear
But in thy train, beauty and blooming JOY
pass, hand in hand, and young eyed hope,
whose glauce, not dimmet, yet sottened by
toHc h Of care. looks forward still; and SC.
r,ous happiness lie on thy heart safe and
shclterca guest.

GA hair 'twixt south and southwest SID"
to divine to which class of the population
man belonged. 1t is SAID, however, that
many of the most respectable Spaniards are
as punctilious on this point as the most scru-
pulous Yankee could be,

few generations, 1t would require more nice
ty of distinction than the knight Of old pos
sessed, who could

days, were the Anniversary of Independ-
ence. when the gray haired brethren of the
Cincinnati, assembled around their illustri-
GUS President General, lmany Of them seam,
ed with scars, and all bearing the badge of
the most honored association anon Earth.
These venerated forms are now rarely to be
seen, and soon will be seen no more, but
like Ossan's shadowy heroes. they will 'ap-
pear through the mists of Time, and their
heroic lives and actions will inspire the Bards
of Liberty, while Liberty exists to bless man.
kind.


Notwithstanding his great occupation in
public affairs, the First President by no
means neglected his private concerns. He
was in the habit of receiving regular and
lengthy reports from the agents of his es.
tates in Virginia. and directed by letter the
management of these extensive establish
ments, with both consumate skill and sue
cess He also inspected the weekly accounts
and disbursements of his household in Phila-
delpha. Indeed, nothing seemed to es-
cape the seeming mind of this wonderful
man, "who had time for all things, and did
every thing in its proper time" and in order.


General Washington was practical econ-
omist; while he wished that his style of liv-
ing should be fully in character with his ex-
alted station, he was utterly averse to waste
or extravaganza of any sort. He frequently
reprimanded his first steward Francis, (the
same at whose hotel in New-York the Gem
eral in Chief took leave Of his brother Off
cers.) for expenditures which appeared to
be both unnecessary and extrayagant Fran
els once purchased shad fish at AN unusual
season; it was served up at the Presidents
private table, who remarked that it was vel
ry early for such fish to be in the market.
and demanded the price; the answer was,
three dollars. Washington waved his hand,
and ordered, take it away, Sir; it must new
er be said that my table sets an example of
extravaganza. The mortified Steward re.
moved the rarity untouched.


The First President took considerable
pains, and used frequent stratagens, in en-
deavoring to avoid the numberless manifes.
tations Of attachment and respect which a.
waited him wherever he went. On his Jour-
neys, he charged the courier who would
proceed to engage accommodations at the
inns, by no means to mention the coming of
the President to other than the landlord.-
These precautions but rarely took effect.
and often, when the Chief would suppose
that he had stolen a march upon his old
companions in arms and fellow citizens, a
horseman would be discovered dashing off
at ful speed, and soon would be heard the
trumpet of the volunteer cavalry, and the
village cannon, reused from its bed of ne
glect, where it had lain since warlike times.
would summon I'll within reach of its echoes,
to haste and bid welcome to the man who
was "frst in the hearts of his countrymen."
Every village and little hamlet poured forth
their population to greet the arrival of him
whom all delighted to honor. A kind ofju-
bilee attended every where the progress of
the Patriot Chief; for even the school chill


lren, with the curiosity incident to that age
of innocence, would labor hard at the daily
lesson, and leave the birch to hang idly on
the wall, when to see Gencroi Washington
was the expected holiday and reward; and
many of these children, now the parents of
children, while recalling the golden hours
of infancy, will dwell with delight on the
time when they were presented to the Pa
ternal Chief, and recount how they heard
the kindly sounds of his voice; felt the kind
lier touch of his hand; or climbed his knee,
to "share the good mans SMILE" Pure.
HAPPY and honored recollections! they will
descend like tradtionary lore from gener-
alton to generation, venerable to all future
| time.


In the frequent trial of generalship be-
tween the Chief and his ancient comrades
in arms-the one seeking to avoid the testi-


monies of respect and attachment, which the
0ther was equally Stud1ouS TO oHer-tne latc
Colonel Proctor, gallant and distinguished
officer of Artillery, was several times OUT
generalled-the President having reached


the Seat of Government privately and un-


observed. This reused the good old Colo
mel, who declared, ale shall not serve me


SO again; I'll warrant that my matches will


be found lighted next time"


So soon as the first gun would be heard


from the upper extremity of Market street,


venerable citizen was seen to leave his Of


Ace, and moving at more than his usual pace.


ascend the steps of the Presidolead He


gave in no name; he required no ceremony
of introduction, but, making his way to the


family parlor, opened the general gratula-


lation by the first welcome Of Robert Nor.


ris.


At the Ferry of the Susquehannah, lived


a veteran worthy of the Revolutionary day,


where the President always took quarters


on ms JOURNEYS to and from his seat in Vir-


r,nia. AS the boat touched the shore punc-
tuai to the moment and true to his post,
stood Col Rodgers, prepared to hand Mrs.


Washington to his house. 1t was his claim,


his privilege: like the claims at Corona


ton. it had been put in and allowed, and.
verify, the veteran would not have yielded
it to an Emperor.


The late General Charles Scott, had a
! hah of cweaviOu. 1vhAth r

full articles.article:
Among soiders---men WHOSE habits OF lie
are almt : in direct opposition to social ana
,lo,ncstic enipyment--who no are strangers eve
~ where, ID whose profession is TO destroy
their fellow men, it is astonishing what ven
dcrncss and amiabilty OF disposition are ire
ouertly to be met with. If a corrrade DIES
and leaves a widow; or if an object OF DIS
tress presents itself to a reginent-Snch as
a poor traveller, unable to proceed irom
Illness or want subscription is inmca'ate-
ly set on foot, and although rev pence
irot, each be the extent OF the alrs, ye',
with nen whose pay IS 50 llmtce' ~ oears
the credit Of a considerable giit; but II Is not
the amount Of the Subscription nave iooh-
ed to most, it is the generous pronp'i.uo.
with which the measure is adoptfu.--'No'
are such the greatest marks OF tehoerhess
I in the soldier: oftcntimcs has It occuVreu,
F. that an orphan has been lett IN regiment,
and the child has either been supported anu
,,onciIed with The company to "n'eh MS
father belonged, or single soldier mas un'
drrtaken the care nt IT, btleVe one ~
markaslc instance occurred Immediately at
tcr thr hattie of Waterloo--thc infant was
discovered under the carriage OF held
piece. Anothcrs, believe, at this moment
to be found either in the 10th or 10Th regi-
mcnt. That which fell under my own oo-
servation, / will relate; and think II al,
fords unlouhted proof OF the kindsst and


most amiablc heart.


| At the battle Of Talavcra. soldier who had
his wife and child about two years and a
bolf cid in the regiment with him. was Kill
ed His death weighed heavily AT the
heart OF the woman, and together with Sc


we're cold caught in marching, produced a


fever which terminated in her death. iier


infant. thus left fatherlcss and mosherlcss,
became an interesting object of pity. ne


officers of the regiment put the boy IN Tue


care OF woman belonging to their own re-


riment. This woman, however, was drhhk-
ard and the comradc Of the deceased ialnei


perceived that she neglected the child. nc


rrnorted this to the officers, and they deler-


mined TO remove it; but on examination y
} was found that there was no other wo''a''


in the regiment who had claims to he trust
ed more than the person with Whom .he


child already was. Indeed, there are nn'
few wamen permitted to take the field WIN


the soldiers, and these in general are nov
onlv intempcratc, but blunted in their feel-


ings by their own pTivations. :.
!, The couraie, finding much difficulty II
nrov;dinr nurse for the child, declared ina
. he you'd sooner undertake the care OF mn mn
